statement.text: Aortic root replacement (Bentall procedure) is the definitive treatment for aortic root aneurysm in Marfan syndrome, involving replacement of the aortic valve, sinuses of Valsalva, and ascending aorta as a composite graft, with reimplantation of the coronary arteries, typically indicated when the root reaches 5.0 cm or at smaller sizes with risk factors.

explanation.intuition: In Marfan syndrome, the weakest part of the aorta is the root - where the aorta starts and the coronary arteries come off. Instead of patching, we replace this entire section with a prefabricated tube that includes a new valve, then sew the coronary arteries into new holes in the tube.
explanation.key_insight: The Bentall procedure has been the gold standard for decades but requires lifelong anticoagulation for mechanical valves. Valve-sparing root replacement (David procedure) preserves the native valve when possible, avoiding anticoagulation - increasingly preferred in young patients with good valve quality.
explanation.technical_details: Indications for elective root replacement: Marfan with root ≥5.0 cm (ACC/AHA), some advocate 4.5 cm with risk factors (family history dissection, rapid growth >0.5 cm/year, pregnancy planned, severe regurgitation). Bentall technique: excise root, sew composite valve-graft proximally, create coronary buttons, reimplant coronaries to graft. Button technique (preferred) vs Cabrol technique (tube graft to coronary ostia). Valve options: mechanical (Bentall, requires anticoagulation) or bioprosthetic (for women desiring pregnancy, anticoagulation contraindication). Operative mortality: 1-3% in experienced centers. Long-term concerns: pseudoaneurysm at coronary buttons, need for reoperation if tissue extends.

size_thresholds.very_aggressive: ≥4.0 cm if: family history of dissection, growth >0.5 cm/year, severe AR, pregnancy planned

bentall.description: Composite mechanical valve-graft with coronary reimplantation

valve_sparing.david_reimplantation: Native valve reimplanted inside tube graft
valve_sparing.limitations: Requires good valve quality; technically demanding

coronary_reimplantation.button_technique: Coronary ostia excised as buttons, reimplanted to graft
coronary_reimplantation.cabrol_technique: Interposition tube graft from coronaries to main graft (rarely used)

outcomes.reoperation_rate: 5-10% at 10 years for distal aortic disease

definition.@value: Surgical replacement of the aortic root including valve, sinuses, and proximal ascending aorta with a composite graft and coronary reimplantation, typically indicated for root aneurysm in Marfan syndrome.

sources.title: ACC/AHA Guidelines for Thoracic Aortic Disease

learning_objectives: Apply size criteria for elective root replacement in Marfan
clinical_pearls: Marfan root ≥5.0 cm = indication for surgery (some say 4.5 cm)
Button technique for coronary reimplantation is standard
Valve-sparing (David) avoids lifelong anticoagulation - preferred in young patients
Family history of dissection = operate at smaller size
Growth >0.5 cm/year = accelerated progression, consider surgery
Experienced center matters: mortality 1-3% vs 5-10% at low-volume centers

medicalCode.description: Ascending aorta graft with aortic root replacement, valve and coronary reconstruction
